**Concepts**

[]{#non-rock-observation}

##  Non Rock Observation


- Procedural observations that indicate missing, processed, incorrect,
or contaminated sample
- Concept URI token: non-rock-observation


[]{#coked-coal}

###  Coked coal


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- Coke is a grey, hard, and porous fuel with a high carbon content and
few impurities, made by heating coal  in the absence of air
- Concept URI token: coked-coal


[]{#composite-coal-sample}

###  Composite Coal Sample


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- A collection of mulitple samples, combined to form a representative
sample
- Concept URI token: composite-coal-sample


[]{#contamination}

###  Contamination


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- Foreign material introduced to a sample or observation
- Concept URI token: contamination


[]{#core-loss}

###  Core Loss


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- An unidentifiable interval in core due to loss of rock during the
coring and retrieval process
- Concept URI token: core-loss


[]{#fill}

###  Fill


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- Disturbed rock that has settled in place of the interval intended to
be sampled, thereby rendering correct identification impossible

- **Alternate labels:**
Back Fill, 
Fill / Spoil, 
Land Fill, 
Spoil, 

- Concept URI token: fill


[]{#lost-rock}

###  Lost Rock


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- Rock that has been lost in the process of obtaining rock sample
before identification can be performed
- Concept URI token: lost-rock


[]{#mine-dump}

###  Mine Dump


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- Material deliberately discarded during mining operations

- **Alternate labels:**
Dump, 
Waste Dump, 

- Concept URI token: mine-dump


[]{#mine-workings}

###  Mine Workings


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- Material disturbed during the operation of a mine
- Concept URI token: mine-workings


[]{#not-logged}

###  Not Logged


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

- A sample of rock collected but not logged
- Concept URI token: not-logged


[]{#stope}

###  Stope


- Child of:
 [`non-rock-observation`](#non-rock-observation)

[]{#scoria}

######  Scoria


- Child of:
 [`basaltic-glass`](#basaltic-glass)
 [`pyroclastic-rock`](#pyroclastic-rock)

- Highly vesicular, basaltic glass. Bomb-size pyroclast that is
irregular in form and generally very vesicular. In less restricted
usage, a vesicular cindery crust on the surface of andesitic or
basaltic lava, the vesicular nature of which is due to the escape of
volcanic gases before solidification; it is usually heavier, darker,
and more crystalline than pumice. The adj. form, scoriaceous, is
usually applied to pyroclastic ejecta. Cinder is sometimes used
synonymously.
- Concept URI token: scoria

[]{#welded-tuff}

######  Welded tuff


- Child of:
 [`pyroclastic-rock`](#pyroclastic-rock)

- A pyroclastic-rock, of any origin, that was sufficiently hot at the
time of deposition to weld together. A glass-rich pyroclastic rock
that has been indurated by the welding together of its glass shards
under the combined action of the heat retained by particles, the
weight of overlying material, and hot gases. It is generally composed
of silicic pyroclasts and appears banded or streaky.

- **Alternate labels:**
tuff lava

- Concept URI token: welded-tuff

[]{#tactite}

########  Tactite


- Child of:
 [`calc-skarn`](#calc-skarn)
 [`californite`](#californite)

- A calc-silicate rock formed by contact metasomatism of a carbonate
or marly rock. A rock of complex mineralogical composition, formed by
contact metamorphism and metasomatism of carbonate rocks. It is
typically coarse-grained and mostly rich in calcic garnet, calcium-
iron-rich pyroxene, vesuvianite, epidote, wollastonite, and scapolite.
Approximate syn: skarn. Often mined for scheelite (tungsten ore), and
less commonly as decorative dimension stone. See Also: calc-silicate
hornfels

[]{#ophicarbonate}

- Child of:
 [`breccia`](#breccia)
 [`metacarbonate-rock`](#metacarbonate-rock)

- A rock consisting of serpentine and carbonate; the serpentine is
commonly fragmented or brecciated, and veined and impregnated by the
carbonate material (calcite, dolomite or magnesite). It forms by the
serpentinisation of ultramafic rocks and their reaction with
CO2-bearing solutions.
- Concept URI token: ophicarbonate


[]{#ophicalcite}

#######  Ophicalcite


- Child of:
 [`ophicarbonate`](#ophicarbonate)

- Strictly an ophicarbonate where calcite is the predominant
carbonate, but it has been traditionally used as a synonym of
ophicarbonate. A recrystallised metamorphic rock composed of calcite
and serpentine, commonly formed by dedolomitisation of a siliceous
dolostone. Some ophicalcites are highly veined and brecciated and are
associated with serpentinite.
- Concept URI token: ophicalcite

exception) containing igneous and impact-melted clasts.  Like

they probably do not come from the same parent asteroid as either EH
or EL chondrites. Meteoritical Society Code: Aubrite

formed through other means. A nonclastic sedimentary rock composed
primarily of minerals produced from a saline solution as a result of
extensive or total evaporation of the water. Examples include gypsum,

[]{#banded-iron-formation}

#######  Banded iron formation


- Child of:
 [`evaporite`](#evaporite)

- Iron-rich rocks almost always of Precambrian age, predominantly
associated with the great oxygenation event (GOE) about 2.3-2.8
billion years ago. They typically consist of repeated, thin iron oxide
layers. The oxide bands are dark grey to to black magnetite (Fe3O4) or
hematite (Fe2O3), alternating with bands of iron-poor shales and
cherts, usually red in color, of similar thickness, or iron rich
silicates and carbonates, including siderite, ankerite, riebeckite
etc.

- **Alternate labels:**
B.I.F., 
BIF, 
Banded-Iron-Formation, 
Carbonate Iron Formation, 
Magnetite Iron Formation, 
Oxide iron formation, 

- Concept URI token: banded-iron-formation

[]{#itabirite}

########  Itabirite


- Child of:
 [`banded-iron-formation`](#banded-iron-formation)

- A laminated, metamorphosed oxide-facies iron formation in which (1)
the original chert or jasper bands have been recrystallised into
megascopically distinguishable grains of quartz and (2) the iron is
present as thin layers of hematite, magnetite, or martite (Dorr &amp;
Barbosa, 1963). The term was originally applied in Itabira, Brazil, to
a high-grade, massive specular-hematite ore (66% iron) associated with
a schistose rock composed of granular quartz and scaly hematite. The
term is now widely used outside Brazil.
- Concept URI token: itabirite


[]{#jaspillite}

########  Jaspillite


- Child of:
 [`banded-iron-formation`](#banded-iron-formation)

- A siliceous or metamorphosed banded ironstone, including iron-rich
quartzites, interbedded jasper and iron oxides. They are usually
mixtures of quartz and magnetite and/or hematite. They constitute many
low grade iron ore deposits, collectively forming the largest
accumulations of iron on the Earth (hundreds of megatons and
more).Also a trade name for red, hematitized varieties of jasper.

- **Alternate labels:**
Jaspilite

- Concept URI token: jaspillite

[]{#buchite}

######  Buchite


- Child of:
 [`contact-metamorphic-glassy-rock`](#contact-metamorphic-glassy-rock)

metamorphism in volcanic to subvolcanic settings or generated by
combustion metamorphism.
- Concept URI token: buchite


[]{#clinker}

#######  Clinker


- Child of:
 [`buchite`](#buchite)

- Fused or partly fused coal ash, a byproduct of combustion.
Characteristic features of clinkers is its resemblance to pavement
brick (klinkaerd) and a 'metallic' sound when hit by a hammer.
Clinkers are the most common rocks found in burning coal mining dumps
and are usually red or pink, hard, having well preserved shaly
texture. They are usually composed of quartz, partially/fully
dehydrated clay minerals, and minor mullite. ref: ACSG, 2
- Concept URI token: clinker

- Child of:

[]{#scoria}

- Child of:
 [`basaltic-glass`](#basaltic-glass)
 [`pyroclastic-rock`](#pyroclastic-rock)

basaltic lava, the vesicular nature of which is due to the escape of
volcanic gases before solidification; it is usually heavier, darker,
and more crystalline than pumice. The adj. form, scoriaceous, is
usually applied to pyroclastic ejecta. Cinder is sometimes used
synonymously.

Isophyre,

[]{#apache-tears}

########  Apache Tears


- Child of:
 [`obsidian`](#obsidian)

- 'Apache tears' originate from siliceous lava flows, lava domes or
ash-flow tuffs, often in close association with or embedded in, gray
perlite. The spherules occur as cores within perlite masses that
typically exhibit concentrically curved, onion-skin fractures. Their
formation is apparently related to differential cooling and differing
alkali and water contents.
- Concept URI token: apache-tears


[]{#fire-obsidian}

########  Fire Obsidian


- Child of:
 [`obsidian`](#obsidian)

- An iridescent variety of obsidian. Its 'fire' is caused by thin
layers of microcrystals of magnetite (which are approximately the
thickness of a wavelength of light). The colour of Rainbow Obsidian
occurs from a much thicker volume of the specimen (Nadin, 2007).
- Concept URI token: fire-obsidian


[]{#macusanite}

########  Macusanite


- Child of:
 [`obsidian`](#obsidian)

- A natural glass of composition similar to some granite pegmatites.
Most typically found as pale yellow-green transparent alluvial
pebbles. The glass usually has abundant well developed micro crystals
floating in it, including the rare quartz-like mineral Virgilite for
which this is the type locality.

- **Alternate labels:**
Macusani glass

- Concept URI token: macusanite

[]{#marekanite}

########  Marekanite


- Child of:
 [`obsidian`](#obsidian)

- Obsidian that occurs as rounded to subangular bodies, usually less
than 2 inches (5.1 cm) in diameter and having indented surfaces. These
bodies occur in masses of perlite and are of special interest because
of their low water content as compared with the surrounding perlite.
The name is from the Marekanka River, Okhotsk, Siberia, Russia.
Marekanite (obsidian balls) have also been found at Cerro Tijerina,
central Nicaragua and appear identical to apache tears. Compare with
apache tears.
- Concept URI token: marekanite

[]{#reticulite}

########  Reticulite


- Child of:
 [`pumice`](#pumice)

- An extremely vesiculated variety of pumice consisting of a broken
network of glass threads which join a series of points forming a
polyhedral space lattice. It is formed from pumice by the collapse of
the walls of adjacent vesicles and the retraction of the liquid into
threads which form the perimeters of the former polygonal faces. The
threads are usually of triangular cross section, indicating chilling,
before rounding could take place. Such rock has generally been known
by Dana's name, thread-lace scoria.
- Concept URI token: reticulite

[]{#orthoquartzite}

#####  Orthoquartzite


- Child of:
 [`quartzite`](#quartzite)
 [`silicate-sandstone`](#silicate-sandstone)

- An indurated silicate-sandstone that is made up almost exclusively
of quartz sand (with or without chert), that is relatively free of or
lacks a fine-grained matrix; a hard but unmetamorphosed 'pure quartz
sandstone', derived by secondary silicification; a quartzite of
sedimentary origin, or a pure quartz sandstone. Typically a sandstone
comprising more than 90% to 95% detrital quartz and chert grains that
are well-sorted, well-rounded, and cemented primarily with secondary
quartz (sometimes with carbonate).

[]{#secondary-quartzite}

#####  Secondary-quartzite


- Child of:
 [`metasomatic-rock`](#metasomatic-rock)
 [`quartzite`](#quartzite)

- A medium to low-temperature metasomatic rock mainly composed of
quartz with subsidiary high-alumina minerals, such as pyrophyllite,
diaspore, alunite and kaolinite. Common accessories include fluorite,
dumortierite and lazulite. Secondary-quartzites are associated with
volcanic and subvolcanic rocks of rhyolitic to andesitic composition.
Normally they form as replacements of acid igneous rocks and more
rarely of sedimentary rocks. They may host mineral deposits of
alunite, pyrophyllite, Au, Cu, Sb and Hg.
- Concept URI token: secondary-quartzite
